DIV1.P: THE MINOR, A COMEDY. Written by Mr. FOOTE. As it is now acting at the New Theatre in the Hay-Market. By Authority from the Lord Chamberlain. Tantum Religio potuit Suadere Malorum.

LONDON: Printed, and Sold by J. COOTE, in Pater-noster Row; G. KEARSLY, in Ludgate-street; T. DAVIES, in Russel-street, Covent-Garden; C. ETHERINGTON, York; W. CHACE, Norwich; P. WILSON, Dublin; R. FLEMING, Edinburgh; and all other Booksellers. MDCCLX. [Price One Shilling and Sixpence.]

DIV1.HEAD: TO HIS GRACE WILLIAM Duke of DEVONSHIRE, Lord Chamberlain of his Majesty's Houshold.
DIV1.P: THE MINOR, who is indebted for his appear∣ance on the stage, to your grace's indulgence, begs leave to desire your grace's further protection, at his entering into the world.

Though the allegiance due from the whole dramatic people to your grace's station, might place this address in the light of a natural tribute; yet, my lord, I should not have taken that liberty with the duke of Devonshire, if I could not, at the same time, plead some little utility in the design of my piece; and add, that the public approbation has stamped a value on the execution.

The law, which threw the stage under the absolute government of a lord chamberlain, could not fail to fill the minds of all the objects of that power, with very gloomy apprehensions; they found themselves (through their own licentiousness, it must be confess'd) in a more precarious dependant state, than any other of his majesty's subjects. But when their direction was lodged in the hands of a nobleman, whose an∣cestors had so successfully struggled for national liber∣ty, they ceased to fear for their own. It was not from a patron of the liberal arts, they were to expect an oppressor; it was not from the friend of freedom, and of man, they were to dread partial monopolies, or the establishment of petty tyrannies.
Their warmest wishes are accomplished; none of their rights have been invaded, except, what without the first poetic authority, I should not venture to call a right, the Jure Nocendi.

Your tenderness, my lord, for all the followers of the Muses, has been in no instance more conspicuous, than in your late favour to me, the meanest of their train; your grace has thrown open (for those who are deny'd admittance into the palaces of Parnassus) a cottage on its borders, where the unhappy migrants may be, if not magnificently, at least, hospitably en∣tertained.

I shall detain your grace no longer, than just to eccho the public voice, that, for the honour, progress, and perfection of letters, your grace may long conti∣nue their candid CENSOR, who have always been their generous protector.
I have the honor, my lord, to be, with the greatest respect, and gratitude,

CLOSER.SIGNED: Your grace's most dutiful, Most oblig'd, And obedient servant, SAMUEL FOOTE.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: BUT are you sure he has leave?

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Certain.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: I'm damn'd glad on't. For now we shall have a laugh, either with him or at him, it does not signify which.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Not a farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: D'you know his scheme?

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Not I. But is not the door of the little theatre open?

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Yes. Who is that fellow that seems to stand centry there?

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: By his tatter'd garb, and meagre visage, he must be one of the troop.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: I'll call him. Holo, Mr. —
What, is there any thing going on over the way?

SP.SPEAKER: PEARSE.
SP.P: A rehearsal.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Of what?

SP.SPEAKER: PEARSE.
SP.P: A new piece.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Foote's?

SP.SPEAKER: PEARSE.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Is he there?

SP.SPEAKER: PEARSE.
SP.P: He is.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Zounds, let's go and see what he is about.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Come along then.Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Sir, this will never do, you must get rid of your high notes, and country cant. Oh, 'tis the true stroling —

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, what, hard at it, my boy!— Here's your old friend Canker and I come for a peep. Well, and hey, what is your plan?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Plan?

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Ay, what are your characters? Give us your groupe; how is your cloth fill'd?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Characters!

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P:
Ay.—Come, come, communicate. What, man, we will lend thee a lift. I have a damn'd fine original for thee, an aunt of my own, just come from the north, with the true Newcastle bur in her throat; and a nose and a chin.—I am afraid she is not well enough known: But I have a remedy for that. I'll bring her the first night of your piece, place her in a con∣spicuous station, and whisper the secret to the
whole house. That will be damn'd fine, won't it?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Oh, delicious!

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: But don't name me. For if she smokes me, for the author, I shall be dash'd out of her codicil in a hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Oh, never fear me. But I shou'd think your uncle Tom a better character.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: What, the politician?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Ay; that every day, after dinner, as soon as the cloth is remov'd, fights the battle of Min∣den, batters the French with cherry-stones, and pursues 'em to the banks of the Rhine, in a stream of spilt port.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Oh, damn it, he'll do.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Or what say you to your father-in-law, Sir Timothy? Who, tho' as broken-winded as a Hounslow post horse, is eternally chaunting Venetian ballads. Kata tore cara higlia.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Admirable! by heavens! — Have you got 'em?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Then in with 'em, my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Not one.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Pr'ythee why not?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Why look'ee, Smart, tho' you are, in the language of the world, my friend, yet there is one thing you, I am sure, love better than any body.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: No, pr'ythee —

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: How now, am I sure that you, who so readily give up your relations, may not have some design upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Why, as soon as my characters begin to circulate a little successfully, my mouth is stopp'd in a minute, by the clamour of your relations, — Oh, damme, — 'tis a shame, — it shoul'd not be, — people of distinction brought upon the stage. — And so out of compliment to your cousins I am to be beggar'd, for treat∣ing the public with the follies of your family, at your own request.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: How can you think I wou'd be such a dog. What the devil, then, are we to have nothing personal? Give us the actors however.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Oh, that's stale. Besides, I think they have, of all men, the best right to complain.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: How so?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Because, by rendering them ridiculous in their profession, you, at the same time, injure their pockets. Now, as to the other gentry, they have providentially something besides their understanding to rely on; and the only injury they can receive is, that the whole town is then diverted, with what before, was only the amusement of private parties.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Give us then a national portrait: a Scotch∣man or an Irishman.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P:
If you mean merely the dialect of the two countries, I can't think it either a subject of satyr or humour; it is an accidental unhappi∣ness, for which a man is no more accountable, than the colour of his hair. Now affecta∣tion I take to be the true comic object. If, in∣deed, a north Briton, struck with a scheme of reformation, should advance from the banks of the Tweed, to teach the English the true pro∣nunciation of their own language, he would, I think, merit your laughter: nor would a Dub∣lin mechanic, who, from heading the Liberty boys in a skirmish on Ormond Quay, should think he had a right to prescribe military laws
to the first commander in Europe, be a less ridiculous object.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Are there such?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: If you mean that the blunders of a few pea∣sants, or the partial principles of a single scoun∣drel, are to stand as characteristical marks of a whole country; your pride may produce a laugh, but, believe me, it is at the expence of your understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Heyday, what a system is here! Laws for laughing! And pray, sage Sir, instruct us when we may laugh with propriety.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: At an old beau, a superannuated beauty, a military coward, a stuttering orator, or a gouty dancer. In short, whoever affects to be what he is not, or strives to be what he cannot, is an object worthy the poet's pen, and your mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Psha, I don't know what you mean by your is nots, and cannots — damn'd abstruse jar∣gon. Ha, Canker.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Well, but if you will not give us persons, let us have things. Treat us with a modern amour, or a state intrigue, or a —

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: And so amuse the public ear, at the expence of private peace. You must excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: And so, with these principles, you expect to thrive on this spot?

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: No, no, it won't do. I tell thee the plain roast and boil'd of the theatres will never do at this table. We must have high season'd ragoûts, and rich sauces.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Why, perhaps, by way of desert, I may produce something that may hit your palate.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: Your bill of fare.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: What think you of one of those itinerant field orators, who tho' at declar'd enmity with common sense, have the address to poison the principles, and, at the same time, pick the pockets, of half our industrious fellow sub∣jects.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Have a care. Dangerous ground. Ludere cum sacris, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Now I look upon it in a different manner. I consider these gentlemen in the light of public performers, like myself; and whether we ex∣hibit at Tottenham-court, or the Hay-market, our purpose is the same, and the place is im∣material.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Why, indeed if it be considered—

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Nay, more, I must beg leave to assert, that ridicule is the only antidote against this perni∣cious poison. This is a madness that argument can never cure: and, should a little wholsome severity be apply'd, persecution would be the immediate cry: where then can we have re∣course, but to the comic muse; perhaps, the archness and severity of her smile, may redress an evil, that the Laws cannot reach, or reason reclaim.

SP.SPEAKER: CANKER.
SP.P: Why, if it does not cure those already di∣stemper'd, it may be a means to stop the in∣fection.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: But how is your scheme conducted?

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Of that you may judge. We are just going upon a repetition of the piece. I should be glad to have your opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: We will give it you.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: One indulgence: As you are Englishmen, I think, I need not beg, that as from necessity most of my performers are new, you will al∣low for their inexperience, and encourage their timidity.

SP.SPEAKER: SMART.
SP.P: But reasonable.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Come then, prompter begin.

SP.SPEAKER: PEARSE.
SP.P: Lord, sir, we are all at a stand.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: What's the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: PEARSE.
SP.P: Mrs. O-Shochnesy has return'd the part of the bawd; she says she is a gentlewoman, and it would be a reflection on her family to do any such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: PEARSE.
SP.P: If it had been only a whore, says she, I should not have minded it; because no lady need be asham'd of doing that.

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTE.
SP.P: Well, there is no help for it; but these gentlemen must not be disappointed. Well, I'll do the character myself.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.
DIV2.STAGE: Sir WILLIAM WEALTHY, and Mr. RICHARD WEALTHY.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: COME, come, brother, I know the world. People, who have their at∣tention eternally fix'd upon one ob∣ject, can't help being a little narrow in their notions.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: A sagacious remark that, and highly pro∣bable, that we merchants, who maintain a constant correspondence with the four quarters of the world, should know less of it than you fashionable fellows, whose whole experience is bounded by Westminster bridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Nay, brother, as a proof that I am not blind to the benefit of travelling, George, you know, has been in Germany these four years.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Where he is well grounded in gaming and gluttony; France has furnish'd him with fawn∣ing and flattery; Italy equip'd him with ca∣priols and cantatas: and thus accomplish'd, my young gentleman is return'd with a cargo of whores, cooks, valets de chambre', and fiddlesticks, a most valuable member of the British commonwealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: You dislike then my system of education.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Most sincerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: The whole?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Every particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: The early part, I should imagine, might merit your approbation.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Least of all. What, I suppose, because he has run the gauntlet thro' a public school; where, at sixteen, he had practis'd more vices than he would otherwise have heard of at sixty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Ha, ha, prejudice!

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Then, indeed, you remov'd him to the uni∣versity; where, lest his morals should be mend∣ed, and his understanding improv'd, you fairly set him free from the restraint of the one, and the drudgery of the other, by the priviledg'd distinction of a silk gown and velvet cap.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: And all these evils, you think, a city-edu∣cation would have prevented?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Doubtless. — Proverbs, proverbs, brother William, convey wholesome instruction. Idle∣ness is the root of all evil. Regular hours, constant employment, and good example, can't fail to form the mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Why truly, brother, had you stuck to your old civic vices, hypocrisy, couzenage, and ava∣rice, I don't know, whether I might not have committed George to your care; but, you cockneys now beat us suburbians at our own weapons. What, old boy, times are chang'd since the date of thy intendures; when the sleek, crop-ear'd 'prentice us'd to dangle after his mistress, with the great gilt Bible under his arm, to St. Bride's, on a Sunday; bring home the text, repeat the divisions of the discourse, dine at twelve, and regale, upon a gaudy day, with buns and beer at Islington, or Mile-End.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Wonderfully facetious!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Our modern lads are of a different metal. They have their gaming clubs in the garden, their little lodgings, the snug depositories of their rusty swords, and occasional bag-wigs; their horses for the turf; ay, and their com∣missions of bankruptcy too, before they are well out of their time.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Infamous aspersion!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: But the last meeting at Newmarket lord Lofty receiv'd, at the hazard table, the iden∣tical note from the individual taylor, to whom he had paid it but the day before, for a new set of liveries.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Invention!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: These are anecdotes you will never meet with in your weekly travels from Cateaton-street to your boarded box in Clapham, brother.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: And yet that boarded box, as your prodigal spendthrift proceeds, will soon be the only seat of the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: May be not. Who knows what a refor∣mation our project may produce!

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: I do. None at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Because your means are ill-proportion'd to their end. Were he my son, I would serve him —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: As you have done your daughter. Discard him. But consider, I have but one.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: That would weigh nothing with me: for, was Charlotte to set up a will of her own, and reject the man of my choice, she must expect to share the fate of her sister. I consider fa∣milies as a smaller kind of kingdoms, and would have disobedience in the one as severely punished, as rebellion in the other. Both cut off from their respective societies.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Poor Lucy! But surely you begin to relent. Mayn't I intercede?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P:
Lookee, brother, you know my mind. I will be absolute. If I meddle with the ma∣nagement of your son, it is at your own re∣quest;
but if directly or indirectly you inter∣fere with my banishment of that wilful, head∣strong, disobedient hussy, all ties between us are broke; and I shall no more regard you as a brother, than I do her as a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: I have done. But to return. You think there is probability in my plan?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: I shall attend the issue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: You will lend your aid, however?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: We shall see how you go on.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: A letter, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Oh, from Capias, my attorney. Who brought it?

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: The person is without, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Bid him wait.Reads.Exit Serv.

LETTER.P:
The bearer is the person I promis'd to pro∣cure. I thought it was proper for you to
examine him viva voce. So if you administer a few interrogatories, you will find, by cross questioning him, whether he is a competent per∣son to prosecute the cause you wot of. I wish you a speedy issue: and as there can be no default in your judgment, am of opinion it should be car∣ried into immediate execution. I am,

POSTSCRIPT.P: P. S. The party's name is Samuel Shift. He is an admirable mime, or mimic, and most delectable company; as we experience every Tuesday night at our club, the Magpye and Horse-shoe, Fetter-lane.

SP.P: Very methodical indeed, Mr. Capias. John.
Bid the person, who brought this letter, walk in. Exit Serv. Have you any curiosity, brother?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Not a jot. I must to the Change. In the evening you may find me in my counting-house, or at Jonathan's.Exit R. Wealthy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: You shall hear from me.
Shut the door, John, and remember, I am not at home. Exit Serv. You came from Mr. Capias?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: I did sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Your name, I think, is Shift.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: It is sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Did Mr. Capias drop any hint of my bus'ness with you?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: None. He only said, with his spectacles on his nose, and his hand upon his chin, Sir William Wealthy is a respectable personage, and my client; he wants to retain you in a certain affair, and will open the case, and give you your brief himself: if you adhere to his instructions, and carry your cause, he is gene∣rous, and will discharge your bill without taxation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Ha, ha, my friend Capias to a hair. Well sir, this is no bad specimen of your abilities. But see that the door is fast. Now sir, you are to—

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: A moment's pause, if you please. You must know, Sir William, I am a prodigious admirer of forms. Now Mr. Capias tells me, that it is always the rule, to administer a re∣taining fee before you enter upon the merits.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Oh, sir, I beg your pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Not that I question'd your generosity; but forms you know —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: No apology, I beg. But as we are to have a closer connection, it may not be amiss, by way of introduction, to understand one another a little. Pray sir, where was you born?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: At my father's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Hum.—And what was he?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: A gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: What was you bred?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: A gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: How do you live?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Like a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Cou'd nothing induce you to unbosom yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P:
Loke'e Sir William, there is a kind of some∣thing in your countenance, a certain openness and generosity, a je ne sçai quoi in your man∣ner,
that I will unlock: You shall see me all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: You will oblige me.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: You must know then, that Fortune, which frequently delights to raise the noblest struc∣tures from the simplest foundations; who from a taylor made a pope, from a gin-shop an em∣press, and many a prime minister, from nothing at all, thought fit to raise me to my present height, from the humble employment of Light your Honour, — A link boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: A pleasant fellow. —Who were your parents.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: I was produced, sir, by a left-handed mar∣riage, in the language of the news papers, between an illustrious lamp-lighter, and an eminent itinerant cat and dog butcher. — Cat's meat, and dog's meat.— I dare say, you have heard my mother, sir. But as to this happy pair, I owe little besides my being; I shall drop them where they dropt me, in the street.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P:
My first knowledge of the world I owe to a school, which has produced many a great man; the avenues of the Play-house: There sir, lean∣ing on my extinguish'd link, I learn'd dexterity
from pick-pockets, connivance from constables, politics and fashions from footmen, and the art of making and breaking a promise, from their masters. Here, sirrah, light me across the kennel.—I hope your honour will remember poor Jack,— You ragged rascal, I have no halfpence—I'll pay you the next time I see you.—But, lack-a-day, sir, that time I saw as seldom as his tradesmen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Very well.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: To these accomplishments from without the Theatre, I must add one that I obtain'd within.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: How did you gain admittance there?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: My merit, sir, that, like my link, threw a radiance round me. — A detachment from the head quarters here, took possession in the summer, of a country corporation, where I did the honours of the barn, by sweeping the stage, and clipping the candles. There my skill and address was so conspicuous, that it procur'd me the same office the ensuing winter, at Drury-Lane, where I acquir'd intrepidity; the crown of all my virtues.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: How did you obtain that?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: By my post. For I think, sir, he that dares stand the shot of the gallery in lighting, snuf∣fing, and sweeping, the first night of a new play, may bid defiance to the pillory, with all its customary compliments.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Some truth in that.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: But an unlucky crab-apple, apply'd to my right eye, by a patriot gingerbread baker from the Borough, who would not suffer three dancers from Switzerland, because he hated the French, forced me to a precipitate retreat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Poor devil.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Broglio and Contades have done the same. But as it happen'd, like a tennis-ball, I rose higher from the rebound.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: How so?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: My misfortune, sir, mov'd the compassion of one of our performers, a whimsical man, he took me into his service. To him I owe, what, I believe, will make me useful to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Explain.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P:
Why, sir, my master was remarkably happy in an art, which however disesteemed at pre∣sent,
is, by Tully, reckon'd amonst the per∣fections of an orator, Mimickry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Why you are deeply read, Mr. Shift.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: A smattering. —But as I was saying, sir, nothing came amiss to my master. Bypeds, or quadrupeds; rationals, or animals; from the clamours of the bar, to the cackles of the barn door; from the soporific twang of the tabernacle at Tottenham-Court, to the melo∣dious bray of their long-ear'd brethren in Bun∣hill Fields; all were objects of his imitation, and my attention. In a word, sir, for two whole years, under this professor, I study'd and starv'd, impoverish'd my body, and pam∣per'd my mind, till thinking myself pretty near equal to my master, I made him one of his own bows, and set up for myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: You have been successful, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P:
Pretty well. I can't complain. My art, sir, is a pass-par-tout. I seldom want employment. Let's see how stand my engagements, pulls out a pocket-book, Hum,—hum, —Oh, Wed∣nesday at Mr. Gammut's near Hanover-square; there, there, I shall make a meal upon the Min∣gotti, for her ladyship is in the opera interest: but, however, I shall revenge her cause upon herrival, Mattei. Sunday evening at Lady Susti∣nuto's
concert. Thursday I dine upon the actors, with ten templers, at the Mitre in Fleet-Street. Friday I am to give the amorous parly of two intriguing cats in a gutter, with the disturbing of a hen-roost, at Mr. Deputy Sugarsops, near the Monument. So, sir, you see my hands are full. In short, Sir William, there is not a buck or a turtle devoured within the bills of mortality, but there, I may, if I please, stick a napkin under my chin.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: I'm afraid, Mr. Shift, I must break in a little upon your engagements; but you shall be no loser by the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Command me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Yo can be secret as well as serviceable.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Mute as a mackrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Come hither then. If you betray me to my son.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Scalp me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Enough.—You must know then, the hopes of our family, are, Mr. Shift, center'd in one boy.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: And, I warrant he is a hopeful one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: No interruption I beg. George has been abroad these four years, and from his late be∣haviour, I have reason to believe, that had a certain event happened, which I am afraid he wished, — my death. —

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Yes; that's natural enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Nay, pray, — there wou'd soon be an end to an ancient and honourable family.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Very melancholy indeed. But families, like besoms, will wear to the stumps, and finally fret out, as you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM
SP.P: Pry'thee peace, for five minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: I am tongue-ty'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Now I have projected a scheme to prevent this calamity.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Ay, I should be glad to hear that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: I am going to tell it you.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: George, as I have contriv'd it, shall expe∣rience all the misery of real ruin, without run∣ning the least risque.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Ay, that will be a coup de maîtro.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: I have prevail'd upon his uncle, a wealthy citizen.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: I don't like a city plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: I tell thee it is my own.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: I beg pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: My brother, I say, some time since, wrote him a circumstantial account of my death; upon which, he is returned, in full expectation of succeeding to my estate.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Immediately?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: No; when at age. In about three months.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: I understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P:
Now, sir, guessing into what hands my heedless boy would naturally fall, on his return, I have, in a feign'd character, associated myself
with a set of rascals, who will spread every bait that can flatter folly, inflame extravagance, allure inexperience, or catch credulity. And when by their means, he thinks himself re∣duc'd to the last extremity; lost even to the most distant hope—

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Then will I step in like his guardian-angel, and snatch him from perdition. If, mortify'd by misery, he becomes conscious of his errors, I have sav'd my son; but if, on the other hand, gratitude can't bind, nor ruin reclaim him, I will cast him out, as an alien to my blood, and trust for the support of my name and family to a remoter branch.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Bravely resolv'd. But what part am I to sustain in this drama?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Why George, you are to know, is already stript of what money he could command, by two sharpers: but as I never trust them out of my sight, they can't deceive me.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Out of your sight!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Why, I tell thee, I am one of the knot: an adept in their science, can slip, shuffle, cog, or cut with the best of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: How do you escape your son's notice?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: His firm persuasion of my death, with the extravagance of my disguise.—Why, I wou'd engage to elude your penetration, when I am beau'd out for the baron. But of that by and by. He has recourse, after his ill success, to the cent. per cent. gentry, the usurers, for a far∣ther supply.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Natural enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Pray do you know, — I forget his name, — a wrinkled old fellow, in a thread-bare coat? He sits every morning from twelve till two, in the left corner of Lloyd's coffee-house; and every evening, from five till eight, under the clock, at the Temple-exchange.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: What, little Transfer the broker?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: The same. Do you know him?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Know him! Ay, rot him. It was but last Easter Tuesday, he had me turn'd out at a feast, in Leather-seller's Hall, for singing Room for Cuckolds, like a parrot; and vow'd it meant a reflection upon the whole body corporate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: You have reason to remember him.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Yes, yes. I recommended a minor to him myself, for the loan only of fifty pounds; and wou'd you believe it, as I hope to be sav'd, we din'd, supp'd, and wetted five and thirty guineas upon tick, in meetings at the Cross-keys, in order to settle the terms; and after all, the scoundrel would not lend us a stiver.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Cou'd you personate him?

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: Him! Oh, you shall see me shift into his shamble in a minute: and, with a wither'd face, a bit of a purple nose, a cautionary stammer, and a sleek silver head, I would un∣dertake to deceive even his banker. But to speak the truth, I have a friend that can do this inimitably well. Have not you something of more consequence for me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: I have. Cou'd not you, master Shift, assume another shape? You have attended auctions.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P:
Auctions! a constant puff. Deep in the mystery; a professed connoisseur, from a niger
to a nautilus, from the Apollo Belvidere to a butterfly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: One of these insinuating, oily orators, I will get you to personate: for we must have the plate and jewels in our possession, or they will soon fall into other hands.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: I will do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Within I'll give you farther instructions.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P: I'll follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: You will want materials.

SP.SPEAKER: SHIFT.
SP.P:
Oh, my dress I can be furnished with in five minutes. Exit sir Wil. A whimsical old blade, this. I shall laugh if his scheme mis∣cairies. I have a strange mind to lend it a lift— never had a greater—Pho, a damn'd unnatural connection this of mine!—What have I to do with fathers and guardians! a parcel of preaching, prudent, careful curmudgeonly— dead to pleasures themselves, and the blasters of it in others—Mere dogs in a manger— No, no, I'll veer, tack about, open my budget to the boy, and join in a counter plot. But hold, hold, friend Stephen, see first how the
land lies. Who knows whether this Germa∣niz'd genius has parts to comprehend, or spirit to reward thy merit. There's danger in that, ay, marry is there. 'Egad, before I shift the helm, I'll first examine the coast; and then if there be but a bold shore and a good bottom, have a care, old Square Toes, you will meet with your match.Exit.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter sir GEORGE, LOADER, and Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Let the martin pannels for the vis a vis be carried to Long Acre, and the pye-balls sent to Hall's to be bitted—You will give me leave to be in your debt till the evening, Mr. Loader. I have but just enough left to discharge the ba∣ron; and we must, you know, be punctual with him, for the credit of the country.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Fire him, a snub-nos'd son of a bitch. Le∣vant me, but he got enough last night to pur∣chase a principality amongst his countrymen, the High-dutchians and Hussarians.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: You had your share, Mr. Loader.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P:
Who, I! Lurch me at four, but I was mark'd to the top of your tick, by the baron,
my dear. What, I am no cinque and quater man. Come, shall we have a dip in the hi∣story of the Four Kings, this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Rather too early. Besides, it is the rule abroad, never to engage a-fresh, till our old scores are discharg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Capot me, but those lads abroad are pretty fellows, let 'em say what they will. Here, sir, they will vowel you, from father to son, to the twentieth generation. They wou'd as soon now-a-days, pay a tradesman's bill, as a play debt. All sense of honour is gone, not a sti∣ver stirring. They cou'd as soon raise the dead as two pounds two; nick me, but I have a great mind to tie up, and ruin the rascals—What, has Transfer been here this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Any body here this morning, Dick?

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: No body, your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Repique the Rascal. He promis'd to be here before me.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: I beg your honour's pardon. Mrs. Cole, from the Piazza, was here, between seven and eight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: An early hour for a lady of her calling.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: Mercy on me! The poor gentlewoman is mortally altered since we us'd to lodge there, in our jaunts from Oxford; wrapt up in flan∣nels; all over the rheumatise.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Ay, ay, old Moll is at her last stake.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: She bad me say, she just stopt in her way to the tabernacle; after the exhortation, she says, she'll call again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Exhortation! Oh, I recollect. Well, whilst they only make proselytes from that profession, they are heartily welcome to them. She does not mean to make me a convert?

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: I believe she has some such design upon me; for she offer'd me a book of hymns, a shilling, and a dram, to go along with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: No bad scheme, Dick. Thou hast a fine, sober, psalm-singing countenance; and when thou hast been some time in their trammels, may'st make as able a teacher as the best of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: Laud, sir, I want learning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Oh, the spirit, the spirit will supply all that Dick, never fear.
SP.STAGE: Enter sir WILLIAM, as a German baron.
SP.P: My dear baron, what news from the Hay∣market? What says the Florenza? Does she yield? Shall I be happy? Say yes, and com∣mand my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: I was never did see so fine a woman since I was leave Hamburgh; dere was all de colour, all red and white, dat was quite natural; point d'artifice. Then she was dance and sing—I vow to heaven, I was never see de like.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: But how did she receive my embassy? What hopes?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Why dere was monsieur le chevalier, when I first enter, dree or four damn'd queer peo∣ple; ah, ah, drought I, by gad I guess your business. Dere was one fat big woman's, dat I know long time: le valet de chambre was tell me dat she came from a grand merchand; by your leave, stick to your shop; or, if you must have de pretty girl, dere is de play-hous, dat do very well for you; but for de opera, par∣doner, by gar dat is meat for your master.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Insolent mechanic!—but she despis'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Ah, may for't, he is damn'd rich, has beaucoup de guineas; but after de fat woman was go, I was tell the signora, madam, der is one certain chevalier of dis country, who has travell'd, see de word, bien fait, well made, beaucoup d'Esprit, a great deal of monies, who beg, by gar, to have de honour to throw him∣self at your feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Well, well, baron.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: She aska your name; as soon as I tell her, aha, by gar, dans an instant, she melt like de lomp of sugar: she run to her bureau, and, in de minute, return wid de paper.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Give it me. Reads.

STAGE.HI: Les preliminaires d'une traité entre le cheva∣lier Wealthy, and la signora Diamenti.

SP.P: A bagatelle, a trifle: She shall have it.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Harkee, knight, what is all that there out∣landish stuff?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Read, read. The eloquence of angels, my dear baron.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Slam me, but the man's mad! I don't un∣derstand their Gibberish — What is it in English?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: The preliminaries of a subsidiary treaty, be∣tween sir G. Wealthy, and signora Florence; That the said signora will resign the possession of her person to the said sir George, on the payment of three hundred guineas monthly, for equipage, table, domestics, dress, dogs, and diamonds; her debts to be duly discharged, and a note advanced of five hundred, by way of entrance.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Zounds, what a cormorant! She must be devilish handsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: I am told so.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Told so! why did you never see her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: No; and possibly never may, but from my box at the opera.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Hey-day. Why what the devil—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Ha, ha, you stare, I don't wonder at it. This is an elegant refinement, unknown to the gross voluptuaries of this part of the world. This is, Mr. Loader, what may be called a debt to your dignity: for an opera girl is as essential a piece of equipage for a man of fa∣shion, as his coach.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: The devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: 'Tis for the vulgar only to enjoy what they possess: the distinction of ranks and conditions are, to have hounds, and never hunt; cooks, and dine in taverns; houses, you never inha∣bit; and mistresses, you never enjoy —

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: And debts you never pay. Egad, I am not surpriz'd at it; if this be your trade, no won∣der that you want money for necessaries, when you give such a damn'd deal for nothing at all.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Mrs. Cole, to wait upon your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: My dear baron, run, dispatch my affair, con∣clude my treaty, and thank her for the very reasonable conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Mr. Loader, shall I trouble you to introduce the lady. She is, I think, your acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Who, old Moll! Ay, ay, she's your mar∣ket woman. I wou'd not give six-pence for your signoras. One armful of good, whole∣some British beauty, is worth a ship-load of their trapsing, tawdry trollops. But hark'ee, baron, how much for the table? Why she must have a devilish large family, or a mon∣strous stomach.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Ay, ay, dere is her maden la complaisante to walk in de park, and to go to de play; two broders, deux valets, dree Spanish lap-dogs, and de monkey.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P:
Strip me, if I would set five shillings against the whole gang. May my partner renounce,
with the game in his hand, if I were you, knight, if I would not —Ex. Bar.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: But the lady waits. Ex. Load. A strange fellow this. What a whimsical jargon he talks. Not an idea abstracted from play. To say truth, I am sincerely sick of my acquaintance: But, however, I have the first people in the kingdom to keep me in countenance. Death and the dice level all distinctions.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. COLE, supported by LOADER and DICK.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Gently, gently, good Mr. Loader.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Come along, old Moll. Why, you jade, you look as rosy this morning, I must have a smack at your muns. Here, taste her, she is as good as old hock to get you a stomach.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Fye, Mr. Loader, I thought you had for∣got me.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: I forget you! I would as soon forget what is trumps.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P:
Softly, softly, young man. There, there, mighty well. And how does your honour do?
I han't seen your honour, I can't tell the— Oh, mercy on me, there's a twinge —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: What is the matter, Mrs. Cole!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: My old disorder, the rheumatise; I ha'n't been able to get a wink of — Oh law, what, you have been in town these two days.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Since Wednesday.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: And never once call'd upon old Cole. No, no, I am worn out, thrown by and forgotten, like a tatter'd garment, as Mr. Squintum says. Oh, he is a dear man! But far him I had been a lost sheep; never known the comforts of the new birth; no, —There's your old friend, Kitty Carrot, at home still. What, shall we see you this evening! I have kept the green room for you ever since I heard you were in town.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: What, shall we take a snap at old Moll's. Hey, beldam, have you a good batch of Bur∣gundy abroach?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Bright as a ruby; and for flavour! You know the colonel — He and Jenny Cum∣mins drank three flasks, hand to fist, last night.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: What, and bilk thee of thy share?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Ah, don't mention it, Mr. Loader. No, that's all over with me. The time has been, when I could have earn'd thirty shillings a day by own dry drinking, and the next morning was neither sick nor sorry: But now, O laud, a thimbleful turns me topsy turvey.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Poor old girl!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Ay, I have done with these idle vanities; my thoughts are fix'd upon a better place. What, I suppose, Mr. Loader, you will be for your old friend the black-ey'd girl, from Rosemary-Lane. Ha, ha. Well, 'tis a merry little tit. A thousand pities she's such a repro∣bate!—But she'll mend; her time is not come: all shall have their call, as Mr. Squin∣tum says, sooner or later; regeneration is not the work of a day. No, no, no.—Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Not worse, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Rack, rack, gnaw, gnaw, never easy, a bed or up, all's one. Pray, honest friend, have you any clary, or mint water in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: A case of French drams.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Heaven defend me! I would not touch a dram for the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: They are but cordials, Mrs. Cole. Fetch 'em, you blockhead.Ex. Dick.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Ay, I am a going; a wasting and a wasting, Sir George. What will become of the house when I am gone, heaven knows.—No.—When people are mist, then they are mourn'd. Six∣teen years have I liv'd in the garden, comfor∣tably and creditably; and, tho' I say it, could have got bail any hour of the day: Reputable tradesmen, Sir George, neighbours Mr. Loa∣der knows; no knock me down doings in my house. A set of regular, sedate, sober custo∣mers. No rioters. Sixteen did I say—Ay, eighteen years I have paid scot and lot in the parish of St. Paul's, and during the whole time, no body have said, Mrs. Cole, why do you so? Unless twice that I was before Sir Thomas De Val, and three times in the round-house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Nay, don't weep, Mrs. Cole.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: May I lose deal, with an honour at bottom, if old Moll does not bring tears into my eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P:
However, it is a comfort after all, to think one has past thro' the world with credit and
character. Ay, a good name, as Mr. Squin∣tum says, is better than a gallipot of ointment.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.L: Come, haste, Dick, haste; sorrow is dry.
Here, Moll, shall I fill thee a bumper?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Hold, hold, Mr. Loader. Heaven help you. I could as soon swallow the Thames. Only a sip, to keep the gout out of my stomach.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Why then, here's to thee.—Levant me, but it is supernaculum. — Speak when you have enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: I won't trouble you for the glass; my hands do so tremble and shake, I shall but spill the good creature.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Well pull'd. But now to business. Pr'ythee, Moll, did not I see a tight young wench, in a linnen gown, knock at your door this morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Ay; A young thing from the country.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Could we not get a peep at her this evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Impossible! She is engaged to Sir Timothy Totter. I have taken earnest for her these three months.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Pho, what signifies such a fellow as that. Tip him an old trader, and give her to the knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Tip him an old trader! — Mercy on us, where do you expect to go when you dye, Mr. Loader?

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Crop me, but this Squintum has turn'd her brains.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Nay, Mr. Loader, I think the gentleman has wrought a most happy reformation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Oh, it was a wonderful work. There had I been tossing in a sea of sin, without rudder or compass. And had not the good gentleman piloted me into the harbour of grace, I must have struck against the rocks of reprobation, and have been quite swallow'd up in the whirl∣pool of despair. He was the precious instru∣ment of my spiritual sprinkling.—But however, Sir George, if your mind be set upon a young country thing, to-morrow night I believe I can furnish you.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: As how?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: I have advertis'd this morning, in the register-office, for servants under seventeen; and ten to one but I light on something that will do.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Pillory me, but it has a face.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Truly, consistently with my conscience, I wou'd do any thing for your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Right, Mrs. Cole, never lose sight of that monitor. But pray, how long has this heavenly change been wrought in you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Ever since my last visitation of the gout. Upon my first fit, seven years ago, I began to have my doubts, and my waverings; but I was lost in a labyrinth, and no body to shew me the road. One time, I thought of dying a Roman, which is truly a comfortable commu∣nion enough for one of us: but it wou'd not do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: I went one summer over to Boulogne to re∣pent; and, wou'd you believe it, the bare∣footed, bald-pate beggars, would not give me absolution, without I quitted my business!— Did you ever hear of such a set of scabby— Besides, I could not bear their barbarity. Wou'd you believe it, Mr. Loader, they lock up for their lives, in a nunnery, the prettiest, sweetest, tex`nder, young things!—Oh, six of them, for a season, wou'd finish my business here, and then I shou'd have nothing to do, but to think of hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Brand me, what a country!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Oh, scandalous!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: O no, it would not do. So, in my last ill∣ness, I was wish'd to Mr. Squintum, who stepp'd in with his saving grace, got me with the new birth, and I became, as you see, re∣generate, and another creature.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: Mr. Transfer, sir, has sent to know if your honour be at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Mrs. Cole, I am mortify'd to part with you. But bus'ness, you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: True, sir George. Mr. Loader, your arm —Gently, oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Wou'd you take another thimbleful, Mrs. Cole?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Not a drop—I shall see you this evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Depend upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: To-morrow I hope to suit you—We are to have, at the tabernacle, an occasional hymn, with a thanksgiving sermon for my recovery. After which, I shall call at the register-office, and see what goods my advertisement has brought in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Extremely obliged to you, Mrs. Cole.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P: Or if that shou'd not do, I have a tid bit at home, will suit your stomach. Never brush'd by a beard. Well, heaven bless you—Soft∣ly, have a care, Mr. Loader—Richard, you may as well give me the bottle into the chair, for fear I should be taken ill on the road. Gently —so, so.Exit Mrs. Cole and Loader.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Dick, shew Mr. Transfer in—Ha, ha, what a hodge podge! How the jade has jumb∣led together the carnal and the spiritual; With what ease she reconciles her new birth to her old calling!— No wonder these preachers have plenty of proselytes, whilst they have the address, so comfortably to blend the hitherto jarring interests of the two worlds.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Well, knight, I have hous'd her; but they want you within, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: I'll go to them immediately.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: MY master will come to you pre∣sently.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Mr. Transfer, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Your Honour's very humble. I thought to have found Mr. Loader here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: He will return immediately. Well, Mr. Transfer — but take a chair — you have had a long walk. Mr. Loader, I presume, open'd to you the urgency of my bus'ness.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P:
Ay, ay, the general cry, money, money! I don't know, for my part, where all the mo∣ney is flown to. Formerly a note, with a to∣lerable endorsement, was as current as cash.
If your uncle Richard now would join in this security —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Ay, like enough. I wish you were of age.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: So do I. But as that will be consider'd in the premium —

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: True, true — I see you understand bus'ness— And what sum does your Honour lack at pre∣sent?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Lack! — How much have you brought?

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Who, I? — Dear me, None.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Zounds, none!

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Lack-a-day, none to be had, I think. All the morning have I been upon the hunt. There, Ephraim Barbones, the tallow-chand∣ler, in Thames-street, us'd to be a never-fail∣ing chap; not a guinea to be got there. Then I totter'd away to Nebuchadnezzar Zebulon, in the Old Jewry, but it happen'd to be Sa∣turday; and they never touch on the Sabbath, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Why what the devil can I do?

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Good me, I did not know your honour had been so press'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: My Honour prest! Yes, my Honour is not only prest, but ruin'd, unless I can raise money to redeem it. That blockhead Loader, to depend upon this old doting—

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Well, well, now I declare, I am quite sorry to see your Honour in such a taking.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Damn your sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: But come, don't be cast down: Tho' mo∣ney is not to be had, money's worth may, and that's the same thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: How, dear Transfer?

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Why I have, at my warehouse in the city, ten casks of whale-blubber, a large cargo of Dantzick dowlass, with a curious sortment of Birmingham hafts, and Whitney blankets for exportation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Hey!

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: And stay, stay, then again, at my country-house, the bottom of Gray's-Inn-Lane, there's a hundred tun of fine old hay, only damag'd a little last winter, for want of thatching; with forty load of flint stones.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Well.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Your Honour may have all these for a rea∣sonable profit, and convert them into cash.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Blubber and blankets! Why, you old rascal, do you banter me?

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Who I! O law, marry heaven forbid.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Get out of my — you stuttering scoundrel.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: If your honour would but hear me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Troop, I say, unless you have a mind to go a shorter way than you came. Ex. Tr. And yet there is something so uncommonly ridiculous in his proposal, that were my mind more at ease. Enter LOADER. So, sir, you have recommended me to a fine fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: He can't supply me with a shilling! And wants, besides, to make me a dealer in dowlas.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Ay, and a very good commodity too. People that are upon ways and means, must not be nice, knight. A pretty piece of work you have made here. Thrown up the cards, with the game in your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Why, prythee, of what use wou'd his —

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Use! of every use. Procure you the spank∣ers, my boy. I have a broker, that in a twinkling, shall take off your bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Indeed! Ay, indeed. You sit down to hazard, and not know the chances! I'll call him back.—Holo, Transfer.— A pretty, little, busy, bustling—You may travel miles, before you will meet with his match. If there is one pound in the city, he will get it. He creeps, like a ferret, into their bags, and makes the yellow boys bolt again.
Come hither, little Transfer; what, man, our Minor was a little too hasty; He did not understand trap; knows nothing of the game, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: What I said, was to serve Sir George; as he seem'd—

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: I told him so; Well, well, we will take thy commodities, were they as many more. But try, pr'ythee, if thou coud'st not procure us some of the ready, for present spending.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Let me consider.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Ay, do, come: shuffle thy brains; never fear the baronet. To let a lord of lands want shiners; 'tis a shame.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: I do recollect, in this quarter of the town, an old friend, that us'd to do things in this way.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Who?

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Statute, the scrivener.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Slam me, but he has nick'd the chance.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: A hard man, master Loader.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: No matter.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: His demands are exorbitant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: That is no fault of ours.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Well said, knight.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: But to save time, I had better mention his terms.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Unnecessary.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Five per cent. legal interest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: He shall have it.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Ten, the praemium.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: No more words.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Then, as you are not of age, five more for ensuring your life.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: We will give it.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: As for what he will demand for the risque—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: He shall be satisfy'd.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: You pay the attorney.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Amply, amply. Loader, dispatch him.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: There, there, little Transfer; now every thing is settled. All terms shall be comply'd with, reasonable or unreasonable. What, our principal is a man of honour. Ex. Tr. Hey, my knight, this is doing business. This Pinch is a sure card.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: I had forgot one thing. I am not the prin∣cipal; you pay the brokerage.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Ay, ay; and a handsome present into the bargain, never fear.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: Enough, enough.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Hark'ee, Transfer, we'll take the Birming∣ham hafts and Whitney wares.

SP.SPEAKER: TRANSFER.
SP.P: They shall be forth coming.—You would not have the hay, with the flints!

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Every pebble of 'em. The magistrates of the Borough, baronet, are infirm and gouty. He shall deal them as new pavement. Ex. Tr. So, that's settled. I believe, knight, I can lend you a helping hand as to the last article. I know some traders that will tick: fellows with finery. Not commodities of such clum∣sey conveyance as old Transfer's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: You are obliging.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: I'll do it boy. And get you, into the bar∣gain, a bonny auctioneer, that shall dispose of 'em all in a crack.Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: Your uncle, sir, has been waiting some time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: He comes in a lucky hour. Shew him in. Ex. Dick. Now for a lecture. My situation sha'n't sink my spirits however. Here comes the musty trader, running over with remon∣strances. I must banter the cit.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P:
So, sir, what, I suppose, this is a spice of your foreign breeding, to let your uncle kick
his heels in your hall, whilst your presence chamber is crowded with pimps, bawds, and gamesters.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Oh, a proof of my respect, dear nuncle. Would it have been decent now, nuncle, to have introduc'd you into such company?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Wonderfully considerate! Well, young man, and what do you think will be the end of all this! Here, I have received by the last mail, a quire of your draughts from abroad. I see you were determin'd our neighbours should taste of your magnificence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Yes, I think I did some credit to my country.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: And how are all these to be paid?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: That I submit to you, dear nuncle.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: From me!—Not a souse to keep you from the Counter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Why then let the scoundrels stay. It is their duty. I have other demands, debts of honour, which must be discharg'd.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P:
Here's a diabolical distinction! Here's a pro∣stitution of words!—Honour! Sdeath, that a
rascal, who has pick'd your pocket, shall have his crime gilded with the most sacred distinc∣tion, and his plunder punctually paid, whilst the industrious mechanic, who ministers to your very wants, shall have his debt delay'd, and his demand treated as insolent.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Oh, a truce to this threadbare trumpery, dear nuncle. I confess my folly. But make yourself easy; you won't be troubled with many more of my visits.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: I own I was weak enough to design a short expostulation with you; but as we in the city know the true value of time, I shall take care not to squander away any more of it upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: A prudent resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: One commission, however, I can't dispense with myself from executing.—It was agreed between your father and me, that as he had but one son and I one daughter —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Your gettings should be added to the estate, and my cousin Margery and I squat down to∣gether in the comfortable state of matrimony.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Puppy! Such was our intention. Now his last will claims this contract.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Dispatch, dear nuncle.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Why then, in a word, see me here demand the execution.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: What d'you mean? For me to marry Mar∣gery?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: What, moi-me?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: You, you.—Your answer, ay, or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Why then concisely and briefly, without evasion, equivocation, or farther circumlocu∣tion,—No.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: I am glad of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: So am I.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: But pray, if it would not be too great a fa∣vour, what objections can you have to my daughter? Not that I want to remove 'em, but merely out of curiosity. What objections?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: None. I neither know her, nor have seen her; enquired after her, or ever intend it.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: What, perhaps, I am the stumbling block.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: You have hit it.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Ay, now we come to the point. Well, and pray—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Why it is not so much a dislike to your per∣son, tho' that is exceptionable enough, but your profession, dear nuncle, is an insuperable obstacle.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Good lack! And what harm has that done, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Done! So stain'd, polluted, and tainted the whole mass of your blood, thrown such a blot on your 'scutcheon, as ten regular successions can hardly efface.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: The duce.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: And could you now, consistently with your duty as a faithful guardian, recommend my union with the daughter of a trader?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Why, indeed, I ask pardon; I am afraid I did not weigh this matter as maturely as I ought.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Oh, a horrid, barbarous scheme?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: But then I thought her having the honour to partake of the same flesh and blood with yourself, might prove in some measure, a kind of Fuller's-earth, to scoure out the dirty spots, contracted by commerce.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Besides, here it has been the practice even of peers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Don't mention the unnatural intercourse! Thank heav'n, Mr. Richard Wealthy, my edu∣cation has been in another country; where I have been too well instructed in the value of nobility, to think of intermixing it with the offspring of a Burgois. Why, what apology cou'd I make to my children, for giving them such a mother?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: I did not think of that. Then I must de∣spair, I am afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: I can afford but little hopes. Tho', upon recollection—Is the Grissette pretty?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: A parent may be partial. She is thought so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P:
Ah la jòlie petite Bourgoise; Poor girl, I sin∣cerely pitty her. And I suppose, to procure
her emersion from the mercantile mud, no con∣sideration wou'd be spar'd.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, for such an honour, one wou'd strain a point.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Why then, not totally to destroy your hopes, I do recollect an edict in favour of Britany; that when a man of distinction engages in commerce, his nobility is suffer'd to sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: And upon his quitting the contagious con∣nexion, he is permitted to resume his rank.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: That's fortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: So, nuncle Richard, if you will sell out of the stocks, shut up your counting-house, and quit St. Mary Ax for Grosvenor-square—

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Why, when your rank has had time to rouse itself, for I think your nobility, nuncle, has had a pretty long nap, if the girl's person is pleasing, and the purchase money is adequate to the honour, I may in time, be prevail'd upon to restore her to the right of her family.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: Amazing condescension!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Good-nature is my foible. But, upon my soul, I wou'd not have gone so far for any body else.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: I can contain no longer. Hear me, spend∣thrift, prodigal, do you know, that in ten days your whole revenue won't purchase you a fea∣ther to adorn your empty head.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Hey day, what's the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: And that you derive every acre of your boasted patrimony, from your great uncle, a soap-boiler!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Infamous aspersion!

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: It was his bags, the fruits of his honest in∣dustry, that preserv'd your lazy, beggarly no∣bility. His wealth repair'd your tottering hall, from the ruins of which, even the rats had run.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Better our name had perish'd! insupport∣able! soap-boiler, uncle!

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P:
Traduce a trader, in a country of commerce! It is treason against the community. And, for
your punishment, I wou'd have you restor'd to the sordid condition from whence we drew you. And like your predecessors, the Picts, stript, painted, and fed upon hips, haws, and black-berries.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: A truce, dear haberdasher.

SP.SPEAKER: R. WEALTHY.
SP.P: One pleasure I have, that to this goal you are upon the gallop; but have a care, the sword hangs but by a thread. When next we meet, know me for the master of your fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Insolent mechanic! But that his Bourgois blood would have soil'd my sword—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: What is de matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: A fellow here, upon the credit of a little affinity, has dar'd to upbraid me with being sprung from a soap-boiler.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Vat, you from the boiler of soap!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P:
Aha, begar, dat is anoder ting—And harka
you, mister mounsieur, ha—how dare a you have d'affontry—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: De impertinence to sit down, play wid me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: What is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: A beggarly Bourgois vis a vis, a baron of twenty descents.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: But baron—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Bygar, I am almost asham'd to win of such a low, dirty—Give me my monies, and let a me never see your face.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Why, but baron, you mistake this thing, I know the old buck this fellow prates about.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: May be.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Pigeon me, as true a gentleman as the grand signor. He was, indeed, a good-natur'd oblig∣ing, friendly fellow; and being a great judge of soap, tar, and train oil, he us'd to have it home to his house, and sell it to his acquaint∣ance for ready money, to serve them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Was dat all!

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Upon my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: Oh, dat, dat is anoder ting. Bygar I was afraid he was negotiant.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Nothing like it.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: A gentleman, to enquire for Mr. Loader.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: I come—A pretty son of a bitch, this baron! pimps for the man, picks his pocket, and then wants to kick him out of company, because his uncle was an oil-man.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: I beg pardon, chevalier, I was mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Oh, don't mention it; had the flam been fact, your behaviour was natural enough.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Mr. Smirk, the auctioneer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Shew him in, by all means.Exit Load.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir WILLIAM.
SP.P: You have affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: If you'll walk into the next room, they will be finished in five minutes.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter LOADER, with SHIFT, as SMIRK.

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Here, master Smirk, this is the gentleman. Harkee, knight, did not I tell you, old Moll was your mark. Here she has brought you a pretty piece of man's meat already; as sweet as a nosegay, and as ripe as a cherry, you rogue. Dispatch him, mean time we'll manage the girl.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: You are the principal.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Even so. I have, Mr. Smirk, some things of a considerable value, which I want to dis∣pose of immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: You have.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Could you assist me?

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: Doubtless.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: But directly?

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: We have an auction at twelve. I'll add your cargo to the catalogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Can that be done?

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: Every day's practice: it is for the credit of the sale. Last week, amongst the valuable effects of a gentleman, going abroad, I sold a choice collection of china, with a curious service of plate; though the real party was never master of two Delft dishes, and a dozen of pewter, in all his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Very artificial. But this must be conceal'd.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: Bury'd here. Oh, many an aigrette and so∣litaire have I sold, to discharge a lady's play-debt. But then we must know the parties; otherwise it might be knock'd down to the husband himself. Ha, ha — Hey ho!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: True, upon my word, your profession re∣quires parts.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: No body's more. Did you ever hear, Sir George, what first brought me into the busi∣ness?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Never.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: Quite an accident, as I may say. You must have known my predecessor, Mr. Prig, the greatest man in the world, in his way, ay, or that ever was, or ever will be, quite a jewel of a man, he would touch you up a lot; there was no resisting him. He would force you to bid, whether you would or no. I shall never see his equal.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: You are modest, Mr. Smirk.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: No, no, but his shadow. Far be it from me, to vie with that great man. But as I was saying, my predecessor, Mr. Prig, was to have a sale as it might be on a Saturday. On Fri∣day at noon, I shall never forget the day, he was suddenly seiz'd with a violent cholic. He sent for me to his bed-side, squeez'd me by the hand; dear Smirk, said he, what an acci∣dent! You know what is to-morrow; the greatest shew this season; prints, pictures, bronzes, butterflies, medals, and minionettes; all the world will be there; lady Dy Toss, Mrs. Nankyn, the dutchess of Dupe, and every bo∣dy at all: You see my state, it will be impos∣sible for me to mount. What can I do? It was not for me, you know, to advice that great man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: No, no.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: At last, looking wishfully at me, Smirk, says he, d'you love me? — Mr. Prig, can you doubt it? — I'll put it to the test, says he; sup∣ply my place to-morrow. — I, eager to shew my love, rashly and rapidly replied, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: That was bold.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P:
Absolute madness. But I had gone too far to recede. Then the point was, to prepare for the aweful occasion. The first want that oc∣curr'd to me, was a wig; but this was too ma∣terial an article, to depend on my own judge∣ment. I resolv'd to consult my friends. I told them the affair — you hear, gentlemen, what has happen'd; Mr. Prig, one of the greatest men, in his way, the world ever saw, or ever will, quite a jewel of a man, taken with a violent fit of the cholic; to-morrow, the greatest shew this season; prints, pictures, bronzes, butterflies, medals, and minionettes; every body in the world to be there; lady Dy Toss, Mrs. Nankyn, dutchess of Dupe, and all mankind; it being impossible he should mount, I have consented to sell—They star'd— It is true, gentlemen. Now I should be glad
to have your opinions as to a wig. They were divided: some recommended a tye, others a bag; one mentioned a bob, but was soon over∣rul'd. Now, for my part, I own, I rather inclin'd to the bag; but, to avoid the imputa∣tion of rashness, I resolv'd to take Mrs. Smirk's judgment, my wife, a dear good woman, fine in figure, high in taste, a superior genius, and knows old china like a Nabob.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: What was her decision?

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: I told her the case — My dear, you know what has happen'd. My good friend, Mr. Prig, the greatest man in the world, in his way, that ever was, or ever will be, quite a jewel of a man, a violent fit of the cholic—the greatest shew this season, to-morrow, pictures and every thing in the world; all the world will be there: now, as it is impossible he should, I mount in his stead. You know the importance of a wig; I have ask'd my friends — some recommend a tye, others a bag — what is your opinion? Why, to deal freely, Mr. Smirk, says she, a tye for your round, regular, smiling face would be rather too formal, and a bag too boyish, deficient in dignity for the solemn occasion; were I worthy to advise, you should wear a something between both. I'll be hang'd, if you don't mean a major. I jumpt at the hint, and a major it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: So, that was fixt.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: Finally. But next day, when I came to mount the rostrum, then was the trial. My limbs shook, and my tongue trembled. The first lot was a chamber-utensil, in Chelsea chi∣na, of the pea-green pattern. It occasioned a great laugh; but I got thro' it. Her Grace, indeed, gave me great encouragement. I over∣heard her whisper to lady Dy, Upon my word, Mr. Smirk does it very well. Very well, in∣deed, Mr. Smirk, addressing herself to me. I made an acknowledging bow to her Grace, as in duty bound. But one flower flounc'd invo∣luntarily from me, that day, as I may say. I remember, Dr. Trifle call'd it enthusiastic, and pronounc'd it a presage of my future great∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: What was that?

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P:
Why, sir, the lot was a guido; a single fi∣gure, a marvellous fine performance; well pre∣serv'd, and highly finished. It stuck at five and forty; I, charm'd with the picture, and piqu'd at the people, A going for five and forty, no body more than five and forty?—Pray, ladies and gentlemen, look at this piece, quite flesh and blood, and only wants a touch from the
torch of Prometheus, to start from the canvass and fall a bidding. A general plaudit ensu'd, I bow'd, and in three minutes knock'd it down at sixty-three, ten.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: That was a stroke at least equal to your master.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: O dear me! You did not know the great man, alike in every thing. He had as much to say upon a ribbon as a Raphael. His manner too was inimitably fine. I remember, they took him off at the play-house, some time ago; pleasant, but wrong. Public characters shou'd not be sported with—They are sacred—But we lose time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Oh, in the lobby, on the table, you will find the particulars.

SP.SPEAKER: SMIRK.
SP.P: We shall see you. There will be a world of company. I shall please you. But the great nicety of our art, is the eye. Mark how mine skims round the room. Some bidders are shy, and only advance with a nod; but I nail them. One, two, three, four, five. You will be sur∣pris'd—Ha, ha, ha, — heigh ho.Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: A Most infernal run. Let's see, Pulls out a card Loader a thousand, the Baron two, Tally—Enough to beggar a banker. Every shilling of Transfer's supply exhausted! Nor will even the sale of my moveables prove sufficient to discharge my debts. Death and the devil! In what a complication of calami∣ties has a few days plung'd me! And no re∣source!

SP.SPEAKER: LOADER.
SP.P: Knight, here's old Moll come to wait on you; she has brought the tid bit I spoke of. Shall I bid her send her in?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Pray do.Exit Loader.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. COLE.
SP.P:
Come along Lucy. You bashful baggage. I thought I had silenc'd your scruples. Don't you remember what Mr. Squintum said? A
woman's not worth saving, that won't be guilty of a swinging sin; for then they have matter to repent upon. Here, your honour, I leave her to your management. She is young, ten∣der and timid; does not know what is for her own good: but your honour will soon teach her. I wou'd willingly stay, but I must not lose the lecture.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Upon my credit a fine figure. Awkard— Can't produce her publicly as mine; but she will do for private amusement—Will you be seated miss?—Dumb! Quite a picture! She too wants a touch of the Promethean torch— Will you be so kind, Ma'am, to walk from your frame and take a chair?—Come, pr'ythee, why so coy? Nay, I am not very adroit in the custom of this country. I suppose I must conduct you—Come, miss.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: O, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Child.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: If you have humanity, spare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: In tears! What can this mean? Artifice. A project to raise the price, I suppose. Lookee, my dear, you may save this piece of pathetic for another occasion. It won't do with me: I am no novice—So, child, a truce to your tragedy, I beg.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Indeed you wrong me, sir; indeed you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Wrong you! How came you here, and for what purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: A shameful one. I know it all, and yet be∣lieve me, sir, I am innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Oh, I don't question that. Your pious pa∣troness is a proof of your innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: What can I say to gain your credit? And yet, sir, strong as appearances are against me, by all that's holy, you see me here, a poor di∣strest, involuntary victim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Her style's above the common class; her tears are real.—Rise, child.—How the poor creature trembles!

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Say then I am safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Fear nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: May heaven reward you. I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Pr'ythee, child, collect yourself, and help to unravel this mystery. You came hither willingly. There was no force?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: None.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: You know Mrs. Cole?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Too well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: How came you then to trust her!

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: Mine, sir, is a tedious, melancholy tale.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: And artless too?

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: As innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Give it me.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: It will tire you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: Not if it be true. Be just, and you will find me generous.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P: On that, sir, I rely'd in venturing hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: You did me justice. Trust me with all your story. If you deserve, depend on my pro∣tection.

SP.SPEAKER: LUCY.
SP.P:
Some months ago, sir, I was consider'd as she joint heiress of a respectable, wealthy
merchant; dear to my friends, happy in my prospects, and my father's favourite.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir GEORGE.
SP.P: His name.
